item.title: Pakistan Army Chief Set for Rare Meeting With US President
item.description: President Donald Trump is expected to meet Pakistan’s army chief for talks as the US considers supporting Israeli airstrikes on Iran, a country with a cooperative and complex relationship with the government in Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank, Faseeh Mangi

media:content.media:description: Asim Munir Photographer: Iranian Presidency/Anadolu Agency/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Again Pushes TikTok Sale Deadline With 90-Day Reprieve
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to extend for a third time the deadline for Chinese company ByteDance Ltd. to divest the American operations of TikTok, allowing the social media app to keep running in the US while negotiations proceed.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: TikTok Inc. offices in Culver City, California

item.title: Supreme Court Upholds Curbs on Care for Transgender Minors
item.description: A divided US Supreme Court upheld a Tennessee law that outlaws certain controversial medical treatments for transgender children, preserving similar measures in two dozen states and dealing a fresh blow to LGBTQ rights.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: LGBT activists and supporters rally in support of transgender people at New York City Hall.

item.title: Trump Says Iran Missed Chance for Deal, Vague on Strike Plans
item.description: President Donald Trump said Iran squandered the chance to make a deal over its nuclear enrichment, but declined to say whether the US plans to join Israel’s offensive aimed at destroying the program.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jordan Fabian

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises following an Israeli strike in Tehran on June 17. Photographer: Atta Kenare/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Urges SALT Deal as Lawler Stands Firm on $40,000 Cap
item.description: President Donald Trump expressed optimism that lawmakers could reach a compromise on the state and local tax deduction — a sticking point in his “One Big Beautiful Bill” — even as a key SALT advocate insisted a deal had already been reached.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Representative Mike Lawler

item.title: Modi Disputes Trump’s Version of India-Pakistan Ceasefire
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi disputed President Donald Trump’s claims that trade deals were used to clinch a recent ceasefire with Pakistan, the latest sign of possible strain in the relationship between New Delhi and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta, Prateek Mazumdar, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Narendra Modi

item.title: Thai Conservative Party Quits Ruling Coalition in Blow to PM
item.description: The second-largest party in Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s government quit the ruling coalition, a major setback for the leader facing calls for resignation after blaming her own military for escalating a border dispute with neighbor Cambodia.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Vaccine Panel to Vote on Flu Shots With Mercury
item.description: A panel of key government advisers appointed by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will weigh in on an infrequently used vaccine preservative that has been wrongly linked to autism in the past.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Smith, Damian Garde

media:content.media:description: HHS secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: Trump Activates 2,000 National Guard Soldiers in Los Angeles
item.description: The Trump administration has deployed into duty 2,000 National Guard soldiers in California, even as the state’s governor clashes with the White House over using troops to quell protests over the federal immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Clanton

media:content.media:description: Members of the California National Guard stand guard outside of the Roybal Federal Building in Los Angeles, on June 12.

item.title: Spanish Grid Denies Network Mismanagement on Day of Blackout
item.description: Spanish power grid operator Red Electrica said it managed the network properly on the day of the nationwide blackout in April, clashing with the government’s opinion about the causes of the incident.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: Customers use candlelight in a restaurant during a power outage in Ourense, Spain, on April 28. Photographer: Brais Lorenzo/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran’s Missile Attacks Wane, Allowing Israel to Start Reopening
item.description: Iran’s missile and drone attacks on Israel appear to be subsiding, prompting Israeli authorities to relax some safety restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Marissa Newman

media:content.media:description: Israeli air defenses intercept Iranian missiles over Tel Aviv early on June 18. Photographer: Leo Correa/AP Photo

item.title: Police Have Right to Ban Budapest Pride Event, Minister Says
item.description: A senior minister said Hungary’s police have the right to ban a Pride parade scheduled later this month, in response to an attempt by Budapest’s mayor to organize it under the capital’s auspices.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: The annual Pride event in Budapest in 2023. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

item.title: Colleges Face Major Tax Blow in Trump’s Proposed IRS Rules on Race
item.description: The Trump administration is privately considering unleashing what advocates and critics agree would be one of its biggest cudgels yet to pressure colleges to end slews of programs and practices benefiting students who are racial minorities.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rembert, Amanda Albright, Simone Foxman

media:content.media:description: The Widener Library on the Harvard campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on June 4.

item.title: Republican Who Flip-Flopped on Energy Credits Risks Voters’ Ire
item.description: In the weeks before the House of Representative’s vote to gut clean energy tax credits in President Donald Trump’s sweeping tax and spending bill, Virginia Congresswoman Jen Kiggans cast herself as the leading Republican champion of renewables.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Representative Jen Kiggans, a Republican from Virginia, in Washington in 2024. Photographer: Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc./Getty Images

item.title: Fertilizer Plant Set to Lose License as Trump Squeezes Venezuela
item.description: One of Venezuela’s most valuable overseas assets is set to lose its license to operate in Colombia as part of a US attack on the finances of the Nicolas Maduro regime.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Patricia Laya, Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: A ship arrives at the dock of the Monomeros fertilizer company in Barranquilla, Colombia.

item.title: UN Says It Has Lost Track of Iran’s Near-Bomb-Grade Uranium
item.description: The United Nations nuclear watchdog said the location of Iran’s near-bomb-grade stockpile of enriched uranium cannot currently be verified, as Israel’s ongoing military assault is preventing inspectors from doing their work.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: Satellite view of the Isfahan enrichment facility following Israeli airstrikes, on June 16. Source: Planet Labs PBC

item.title: Iran’s Leader Stays Defiant as Trump Weighs War Intervention
item.description: Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei rejected President Donald Trump’s demands for complete capitulation and predicted “irreparable damage” if the US joins Israel in bombarding his country.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Josh Wingrove, Stephanie Lai, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Israeli air defense systems intercept Iranian missiles over Tel Aviv early on June 18. Photographer: Menahem Kahana/Getty Images

item.title: Orban Confronts Strongest Opposition Poll Surge of His Rule
item.description: Hungary’s opposition Tisza Party surged to an unprecedented 15 percentage point lead over Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s Fidesz in an opinion poll, with more voters now expecting the strongman premier to face defeat in the next elections.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: Peter Magyar

item.title: Khamenei Tells US That Iran Won’t Surrender to Israel
item.description: Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said his country won’t surrender to Israel after US President Donald Trump called for the Islamic Republic’s capitulation amid growing speculation that Washington could enter the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: Khamenei

item.title: Iran-Israel Conflict Spreads to Hacks on Banks, Crypto
item.description: The conflict between Israel and Iran is spilling over into the digital world, inflaming a decades-long campaign of hacks and espionage between two nations renowned for their cyber prowess.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Howell O'Neill, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: A poster bearing the image of Commander-in-Chief of the IRGC Hossein Salami, displayed in front of a Bank Sepah branch in Tehran on June 17, 2025.

item.title: Trump Flexes Security Powers to Keep Global Tariff Goal Alive
item.description: The Trump administration is pressing ahead with another tariff barrage that some trade experts say is more legally sound than the president’s country-by-country duties and may end up having an equally broad effect on imports.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photo by Ludovic MARIN/POOL/AFP/Getty Images Photographer: LUDOVIC MARIN/Getty Images

item.title: South Africa, US to Resume Trade Talks as Tariff Deadline Looms
item.description: South Africa will resume trade talks with the Trump administration on the sidelines of the US-Africa Business Summit next week, with less than a month to go before Washington’s reciprocal tariffs are set to come into effect.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: South Africa's president Cyril Ramaphosa and US President Donald Trump during a meeting in the Oval Office in Washington, DC, on May 21.

item.title: Thai PM Sparks Turmoil After Criticizing Army in Leaked Audio
item.description: Thailand’s prime minister blamed her own military for escalating a border dispute with Cambodia, according to a leaked audio recording, sparking fresh political turmoil in the country as opposition groups called on her to resign.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: Portugal Premier Gets Backing From Opposition in Parliament Vote
item.description: Portuguese Prime Minister Luis Montenegro’s minority government got backing from the two biggest opposition parties in a vote in parliament after his center-right coalition won a snap election in May.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Portuguese Prime Minister Luis Montenegro

item.title: In Tehran, Iranians Brace for What’s Next in Unpredictable War
item.description: With their economy on its knees and a weakened leadership, people in the capital don’t expect things to be the same again.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli, Abeer Abu Omar

media:content.media:description: Locals watch Iran’s air defense systems and Israeli drones and projectiles over Tehran on June 15.

item.title: Bank Indonesia Official Summoned as Witness in Graft Case
item.description: A Bank Indonesia deputy governor will testify this week as a witness in a graft case related to the use of corporate social responsibility funds.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Filianingsih Hendarta Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

item.title: Russia's Faltering Oil Flows Crimp Gains From Rally in Prices
item.description: Crude shipments fell to the lowest since April in the four weeks to June 15
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: The oil tanker Aulis carries a cargo of Russian crude past the Danish island of Agersø on Aug. 1, 2024

item.title: Brazil’s Lula to Push Fiscal Plan Forward Despite Setbacks in Congress
item.description: Brazil’s government has no immediate plans to develop new fiscal measures amid setbacks in Congress, and will instead seek to persuade lawmakers against blocking proposed tax increases, according to two officials with knowledge of the situation.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: RFK Jr.’s Criticism of Fluoride Is Good News for Natural Toothpaste Brands
item.description: Fluoride-free toothpaste sales are jumping as Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and other government officials openly question the safety of the mineral long hailed as a public-health miracle.
item.dc:creator: Redd Brown

item.title: Xi, Trump Take Opposite Sides on Iran-Israel
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Jenni Marsh

media:content.media:description: The destroyed home of the Khatib family following an Iranian missile attack in Tamra, Israel, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. Iran fired several waves of drones and missiles over the last 24 hours, while Israel continued hitting Tehran, killing one more senior military official and setting the state-television complex ablaze with a strike during a live broadcast. Photographer: Kobi Wolf/Bloomberg
